ednote: Eds: CORRECTS: This story has been updated to correct attribution. Wright had told WFIE-TV about the leak, not WSAZ-TV.
title: KY--Coal Ash Leak
headline: Ash leak at Kentucky power plant sends 3 workers to hospital
headline_extended: A Kentucky power plant silo has leaked coal ash and trapped one worker under a pile of the dusty material
description_summary: A Kentucky power plant silo has leaked coal ash and trapped one worker under a pile of the dusty material. He and two others have been sent to a hospital. The leak at the D.B. Wilson Generating Station on Wednesday caused dusty conditions around the plant. Ohio County Sheriff Adam Wright says the workers were trying to loosen a stuck valve inside the silo when ash dumped on them. One was trapped under the pile until a response team pulled him out. Wright says the men’s conditions were not known Wednesday afternoon. The plant is back at full operation.

body_nitf:
CENTERTOWN, Ky. (AP) — A Kentucky power plant silo leaked coal ash and trapped one worker under a pile of the dusty material on Wednesday, sending him and two others who tried to help him to a hospital.

The leak at the D.B. Wilson Generating Station caused dusty conditions around the plant and prompted police to divert traffic and warn motorists of low visibility.

Ohio County Sheriff Adam Wright said a valve inside the silo became stuck open. Three workers went to loosen the valve, and one became stuck under a coal ash pile during the repair. The other two escaped but returned to help him, Wright told WFIE-TV. The plant's emergency response team arrived and pulled the third worker out, and all three were sent to the hospital.

Wright said the men's conditions were not known Wednesday afternoon. The plant was back at full operation, he said.

Federal and state officials were monitoring the air quality, and Wright said it was confirmed safe.

___

This story has been updated to correct attribution. Wright had told WFIE-TV about the leak, not WSAZ-TV.

Health.reason: The document discusses an incident at a Kentucky power plant where a coal ash leak resulted in three workers being hospitalized. While the primary focus is on the accident and the response to it, there are elements related to health, such as the hospitalization of the workers and the monitoring of air quality by federal and state officials. However, the document does not delve deeply into health issues or provide extensive information on health impacts, making it somewhat relevant but not highly so.
